Situation1: Their partner faces a tough decision at work and seeks advice and encouragement.
Situation2: Got a request to attend court to provide testimony when required.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, my husband’s hands wrapped tightly around his coffee mug. He looked at me, eyes searching for reassurance as he explained the impossible choice his boss had given him—either take the fall for a mistake he didn’t make or risk losing his job. He needed me to listen, to comfort him, to help him find the courage to do what was right. I wanted to be there for him, to hold his hand and promise everything would be okay.

But my phone buzzed with a message from the station: I was needed in court tomorrow to testify in a case I’d worked on for months. My testimony could make or break the case, and I knew I had to be there—my duty demanded it. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down on me. My husband’s voice faded into the background as I tried to focus, torn between being the supportive wife he needed and the officer of the law I was sworn to be. My heart ached, knowing I couldn’t give my all to both.
